Chapter 11, Part 2: The Bodhisattva Jewel Topknot
How do bodhisattvas purify the five faculties?
A bodhisattva's faith is unshakable, which is called the faculty of faith.
Practicing diligence without relying on others' teachings is called the faculty of diligence.
Always contemplating enlightenment is called the faculty of mindfulness.
Always cultivating great compassion is called the faculty of concentration.
Embracing wholesome dharmas is called the faculty of wisdom.
Furthermore, believing in the Buddhadharmas is called the faculty of faith.ğŸ”½Seeking the Buddhadharmas is called the faculty of diligence.
Mindful of the Buddhadharmas is called the faculty of mindfulness.
Attaining the Buddha's samÄdhi is called the faculty of concentration.
Cutting off the net of doubts is called the faculty of wisdom.
Furthermore, the mind facing enlightenment without doubt is called the faculty of faith.ğŸ”½Increasing wholesome dharmas is called the faculty of diligence.
Seeking skillful means is called the faculty of mindfulness.
Regarding all sentient beings with an impartial mind is called the faculty of concentration.
Observing the superior, middling, and inferior faculties of sentient beings is called the faculty of wisdom.
Furthermore, a pure and untroubled mind is called the faculty of faith.
Destroying a turbid mind is called the faculty of zeal.ğŸ”½Mindfully recollecting pure dharmas is called the faculty of mindfulness.
Observing the purity of the mind's nature is called the faculty of concentration.
Causing sentient beings to abide in pure dharmas is called the faculty of wisdom.
Furthermore, being far removed from all evil dharmas is called the faculty of faith.
Seeking wholesome dharmas is called the faculty of zeal.
Having attained them, not losing them is called the faculty of mindfulness.
Having attained wholesome dharmas, abiding in accordance with the Dharma is called the faculty of concentration.
Contemplating wholesome, unwholesome, and indeterminate dharmas is called the faculty of wisdom.
Furthermore, the faculty of faith is precisely the mind of giving.
The faculty of zeal is precisely delighting in giving without rest.
The faculty of mindfulness means, having already given, not seeking any karmic rewards.
The faculty of concentration means the mind of equal giving without discrimination.
The faculty of wisdom means not observing the field of blessings and those not worthy of offerings.
Moreover, the faculty of faith is the mind that initially enters the good Dharma.
The faculty of zeal means being able to destroy arrogance.
The faculty of mindfulness means being free from self and what belongs to self.
The faculty of concentration means being far removed from all sixty-two views.
The faculty of wisdom means being free from all evil afflictions.
This is called the bodhisattva's practice of purifying the five faculties.
What is the bodhisattva's practice of purifying the five powers?
Good man!
The bodhisattva-mahÄsattva, being endowed with the five faculties, is not destroyed by any demons, and is therefore called power.

All Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas are unable to reach it, all sentient beings are unable to cause them to regress from the MahÄyÄna mind, all afflictions are unable to destroy it, it is able to cause their minds to be content with few desires, the body obtains great strength, well covers the faculties, and obtains an adamantine body. This is called power.
Good son!
When bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas abide in the power of faith, they never create any evil;
when abiding in the power of vigor, they create all good;
when abiding in the power of mindfulness, they do not lose wholesome dharmas;
when abiding in the power of concentration, they are not destroyed by the five desires and pleasures;
when abiding in the power of wisdom, they are able to be content with few desires and far remove all the bonds and afflictions.
Furthermore, when abiding in the power of faith, one does not follow the words of others;
when abiding in the power of vigor, one seeks goodness without ceasing;
when abiding in the power of mindfulness, one attains dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s;
when abiding in the power of concentration, one expounds the Dharma equally;
when abiding in the power of wisdom, one is able to destroy the doubting minds of all sentient beings.
Furthermore, when abiding in the power of faith, one fully obtains the power of understanding;
when abiding in the power of diligence, one fully possesses the power of diligence;
when abiding in the power of mindfulness, one fully possesses the power of liberation;
when abiding in the power of concentration, one fully possesses the power of vows;
when abiding in the power of wisdom, one fully possesses the power of practices.
Furthermore, when abiding in the power of faith, one sees the faults of stinginess;
when abiding in the power of diligence, one distances oneself from stinginess and greed;
when abiding in the power of mindfulness, one dedicates the wholesome roots cultivated towards enlightenment;
when abiding in the power of concentration, one's mind is impartial;
when abiding in the power of wisdom, one's mind never seeks rewards for giving, morality, or concentration.

Furthermore, when abiding in the power of faith, one is able to distance oneself from all the defilements of breaking precepts;ğŸ”½when abiding in the power of diligence, one fully observes precepts with utmost sincerity;
when abiding in the power of mindfulness, one dedicates the precepts observed towards enlightenment;
when abiding in the power of concentration, one possesses pure stages;
when abiding in the power of wisdom, one distances oneself from precepts that are merely observed.
Furthermore, when abiding in the power of faith, one should avoid hateful thoughts;ğŸ”½when abiding in the power of diligence, one should cultivate patience;
when abiding in the power of mindfulness, one should dedicate one's cultivated patience towards enlightenment;
when abiding in the power of concentration, one should protect all sentient beings;
when abiding in the power of wisdom, one should not discriminate among sentient beings, men, or life spans.
Furthermore, when abiding in the power of faith, one should avoid laziness;
when abiding in the power of diligence, one should cultivate all practices to the ultimate shore;
when abiding in the power of mindfulness, one should dedicate one's cultivated diligence towards enlightenment;
when abiding in the power of concentration, one's body and mind should be tranquil;
when abiding in the power of wisdom, one should not dwell in good or evil.
Furthermore, when abiding in the power of faith, one should avoid all busy affairs;ğŸ”½when abiding in the power of diligence, one should diligently seek the factors of meditation;
when abiding in the power of mindfulness, one should dedicate one's cultivated concentration towards enlightenment;
when abiding in the power of concentration, one's mind should always be in concentration;
When abiding in the power of wisdom, one does not become attached to various concentrations.
Furthermore, when abiding in the power of faith, one distances oneself from ignorance;
when abiding in the power of vigor, one diligently seeks various wholesome [dharmas];
when abiding in the power of mindfulness, one wishes to turn the wisdom cultivated towards bodhi;
when abiding in the power of concentration, one cultivates wholesome thoughts;
when abiding in the power of wisdom, one abides in accordance with the Dharma.
Furthermore, when abiding in the power of faith, one is endowed with the seven powers;
when abiding in the power of vigor, one attains abiding in the seven factors of awakening;
when abiding in the power of mindfulness, one attains the eight foundations of mindfulness;
when abiding in the power of concentration, one leaves behind the seven abodes of consciousness;
when abiding in the power of wisdom, one leaves behind the eight wrong paths.
Furthermore, the mind not turning back from bodhi is called the pure practice of the power of faith of the power of faith;
not grasping or abandoning is called the pure practice of the power of vigor of the power of vigor;
cultivating the four foundations of mindfulness is called the pure practice of the power of mindfulness of the power of mindfulness;
Subduing the mind is called the pure practice of the power of concentration.
Dwelling in the forest and being free from all views and knowing skillful means is called the pure practice of the power of wisdom.
Good son!
How do bodhisattvas purify the practice of the seven factors of enlightenment?ğŸ”½Never losing the factors of enlightenment is called the factor of enlightenment of mindfulness.
Neither grasping nor rejecting samÄdhi is called the factor of enlightenment of discrimination.ğŸ”½Being free from all evil is called the factor of enlightenment of diligence.
Being free from all sorrow is called the factor of enlightenment of joy.
The body and mind being tranquil is called the factor of enlightenment of tranquility.
Obtaining the taste of liberation is called the factor of enlightenment of concentration.
Having accomplished what is to be done is called the factor of enlightenment of equanimity.
Furthermore, not abandoning the bodhi mind is called the factor of enlightenment of mindfulness.
Single-mindedly protecting the Dharma is called the factor of enlightenment of discrimination.
Harmonizing all sentient beings without rest is called the factor of enlightenment of diligence.
Being replete with good dharmas is called the factor of enlightenment of joy.
Being free from all afflictions is called the factor of enlightenment of tranquility.
Able to cause sentient beings to abide in samÄdhi, it is called the factor of samÄdhi awakening.
Causing all sentient beings to know the Dharma realm, it is called the factor of equanimity awakening.
Furthermore, not thinking of the vehicles of Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, it is called the factor of mindfulness awakening.
Discerning the meanings of all Dharma words and phrases, it is called the factor of discrimination awakening.
When seeking wholesome dharmas, the three karmas are unceasing, it is called the factor of vigor awakening.
Free from the mind of enmity and intimacy, it is called the factor of joy awakening.
Abiding in accordance with the Dharma, it is called the factor of tranquility awakening.
Following the various worlds and being able to subdue them, it is called the factor of samÄdhi awakening.
Not observing the two dharmas, it is called the factor of equanimity awakening.
Good man!

Assisting bodhi means being aware of all dharmas and knowing all dharmas, discerning and evaluating all dharmas, knowing the mental natures and mental activities of sentient beings. This is called the factors of awakening and also called the holy practices.

Such noble conduct is not practiced by all ordinary beings, demons, or those with wrong views. It is not practiced through form, sound, smell, taste, or touch. It is not practiced through any characteristics, any feelings, any mind, thought, or consciousness, through seeing, hearing, knowing, or perceiving, through any conceptual thoughts, or through any phenomena. Therefore, it is called noble conduct.

Moreover, noble conduct is neither awareness nor non-awareness, nor is it great awareness. It is able to counteract all phenomena, yet it does not dispute with phenomena. This is called noble conduct.
Noble conduct is the Dharma that assists in attaining enlightenment.
Good man!
How do bodhisattvas purify the practice of the eightfold path?
The eightfold path refers to right view.
What is right view?
Right view is to see all phenomena as being completely equal.
Such right view is not called the view of emptiness.
Why is this?
There is right view that is not the view of emptiness.
Such two views are also called the same view.
Furthermore, the views of self, sentient beings, and emptiness are not called right views, and these three views are also considered the same view.
Moreover, the views of sentient beings, life, and emptiness are not called right views, and these three views are also considered the same view.
Furthermore, the views of self, annihilation, and emptiness are not called right views, and these three views are also considered the same view.
Again, the views of existence, non-existence, and emptiness are not called right views, and these three views are also considered the same view.
There are also four views:
The views of the Buddha, Dharma, Saá¹…gha, and emptiness are called right views, and these four views are not called the view of emptiness.
Good man!
If someone is attached to such views, it is not called right view.
If one is not attached, it is called right view.
Why is it so?
The right view is the view of non-discrimination, equality, and non-duality.
What is meant by the view of equality?
If one thinks that the dharmas of ordinary beings are inferior and the dharmas of those in training are superior, this is called not the view of equality.

The dharmas of ordinary beings are with outflows, while the dharmas of those in training are without outflows. The dharmas of ordinary beings have sustenance, while the dharmas of pratyekabuddhas are without sustenance. The dharmas of ordinary beings are defiled, while the dharmas of bodhisattvas are pure. Ordinary beings are conditioned, while the Buddha is unconditioned. One who sees in this way does not have the view of equality.
If one is able to contemplate the dharmas of ordinary beings up to the dharmas of the Buddha without discrimination, this is called equality.
If one is able to see that the dharmas of ordinary beings are empty up to the dharmas of the Buddha being empty, this is called right view.
Contemplating that the dharmas of ordinary beings arise from causes and conditions, and the dharmas of pratyekabuddhas also arise from conditions, this is called right view.
If one contemplates that the dharmas of ordinary beings are tranquil and the dharmas of bodhisattvas are tranquil, this is called right view.
If one contemplates that the dharmas of ordinary beings are incomplete up to the dharmas of the Buddha also being incomplete, this is called right view.
If one contemplates that self and non-self are without distinction, the view of no distinction is called right view.
If one sees in this way, then one does not see superior, middling, or inferior dharmas, and with regard to all dharmas there is also no discursive thought. This is called right view.
Right view is called seeing nothing;
seeing nothing is precisely right view.
If one sees in this way, this person does not even see a single dharma, the appearance of a single dharma, or the radiance of a single dharma.
Good man!
If one sees in this way, this is called the right view of the Buddha's Dharma.
When this Dharma was being spoken, five hundred bhiká¹£us attained the fruit of arhatship.
Good man!
What is right understanding?
Right understanding is apart from all understanding. Understanding is called wisdom and skillful means.
Contemplating dharmas and knowing dharmas is called right understanding.
Examining all dharmas, which are defiled?
Which are pure?
Having contemplated in this way, one does not at all perceive equality or inequality, and is free from all conceptualization. This is called right contemplation.
What is right speech?
Speech that does not burn oneself or others, does not defile oneself or others, does not give rise to arrogance in oneself or others, does not deceive oneself or others - this is called right speech.

Furthermore, right speech means that whatever is spoken, all dharmas are spoken of as being completely equal, and one is well able to discern the characteristics of conditioned things. This is called right speech.
Furthermore, right speech means speaking of all dharmas as being empty, signless, wishless, unborn, unceasing, neither coming nor going. This is called right speech.
Furthermore, right speech means speaking of conditioned things as suffering, impermanent, and non-self, and of nirvÄá¹‡a as tranquil. This is called right speech.

If there are sentient beings who say that all sentient beings have no life or self, and that all dharmas arise and cease from causes and conditions, like seeds and fruits, this is called right speech.
Pure right speech is the speech of the Buddha, this is called the practice of pure right speech.
What is right action?
Right action is an action that, although able to destroy all actions, is not called an action.
If an action is able to create the cause of tranquility, is neither defiled nor pure, is able to destroy afflictions and prevent them from increasing, this is called right action.
Knowing that actions are like this, yet still creating good actions, and also contemplating that all actions are empty and tranquil, without solidity or happiness, this is called right action.
What is right livelihood?

Right livelihood is a livelihood that does not interfere with one's own or others' bodies, does not increase any evil afflictions, and is not sustained by evil actions, this is called right livelihood.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas purify right livelihood for all beings. With this right livelihood, they vow to head towards enlightenment. This is called right livelihood. Such right livelihood can benefit both oneself and others.
Right effort means diligently making expedient efforts to seek all wholesome dharmas, with a desirous mind that does not cease and is not weary. This is called effort.

Seeking the nature of equality of all dharmas, yet not observing the equality or inequality of dharmas, neither doing nor not doing, and clearly understanding the true nature of dharmas, is called right effort.
Proclaiming the right Dharma to enable all beings to depart from wrong effort, and also knowing the practices cultivated by beings, this is called right effort.
What is right mindfulness?
If one is mindful of giving, morality, patience, effort, meditation, wisdom, and the four immeasurables, this is called right mindfulness.

Moreover, there is right mindfulness, which subdues afflictions and prevents them from arising, does not approach any evil demonic activities, does not fall into evil paths or give rise to evil thoughts, always cultivates all correct and wholesome dharmas, and stays far away from all evil and deviant dharmas. This is called right mindfulness.
Bodhisattvas abiding in this right mindfulness attain the correct aggregate of Å›ramaá¹‡as and the correct fruit of the path. This is called right mindfulness.
What is right concentration?
Cultivating the noble practices, knowing suffering, abandoning the cause, realizing cessation, and cultivating the path. This is called right concentration.
Moreover, there is right concentration, which observes that all dharmas are completely equal.

If one observes that the self is pure, then all is pure. If one observes that the self is empty, then all is empty. Although one makes such observations, one does not enter the correct stage. This is called the right concentration of bodhisattvas.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas abiding in this concentration, in a single thought, attain omniscience. This is called right concentration.
When this Dharma was being spoken, sixteen thousand gods and humans gave rise to the mind of supreme, perfect enlightenment.
Good sons!
What is a bodhisattva's pure divine power practice?
Good sons!
There are five kinds of divine eyes:

One can see the worlds in the ten directions, and the buddhas in the worlds in the ten directions, and the birth and death of sentient beings. What one sees in the ten directions is unobstructed, surpassing all Å›rÄvakas, pratyekabuddhas, and devas and humans.
If a bodhisattva is endowed with these five things, he can clearly see all dharmas. This is called a bodhisattva's pure divine eye practice.
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas attain the divine ear, and hear five kinds of sounds:

Human sounds, non-human sounds, hell sounds, the sounds of the buddhas in the ten directions teaching the Dharma, and the sounds of the languages of all sentient beings. This is called a bodhisattva's pure divine ear practice.
What is a bodhisattva's pure practice of knowing the minds of others?
The knowledge of others' minds also has five kinds:

Fully knowing the minds of all humans and gods, the minds of hell beings, hungry ghosts, and animals, knowing past minds, knowing future minds, and knowing present minds. This is called the bodhisattva's practice of pure knowledge of others' minds.

Moreover, there is the knowledge of others' minds that knows which sentient beings are in the group of right determination, which are in the group of wrong determination, and which are in the indeterminate group. Knowing that these sentient beings have greed, hatred, and delusion, and having understood this, teaching the Dharma accordingly. When sentient beings hear this, they can destroy their afflictions. This is called the bodhisattva's practice of pure knowledge of others' minds.
What is the bodhisattva's practice of pure knowledge of past lives?

They know that this body arises from the causes and conditions of greed, anger, and delusion, and they know that this body arises from the causes and conditions of giving, morality, patience, diligence, concentration, wisdom, kindness, compassion, joy, and equanimity. They know whether this body is complete or incomplete, and they know that this body arises from causes of ignorance, craving, and the four inverted views. They know that because of the causes of giving, this body is endowed with wealth and retinue. Such knowledge is called the bodhisattvas' pure practice of the knowledge of past abodes.
What is the bodhisattvas' pure practice of spiritual powers?
The practice of spiritual powers also has five kinds:
First, manifesting form;
Second, using various languages to expound the Dharma;
Third, being able to understand the mind, thought, and consciousness, etc.;
Fourth, being able to awaken to all dharmas and expound all dharmas. This is called the bodhisattvas' pure practice of spiritual powers.
Good man!

In this way, the five spiritual powers are for the sake of exhausting the contaminants. The bodhisattvas cultivate them but do not exhaust the contaminants, in order to understand all the contaminants.
Why is it so?
It is for the sake of taming sentient beings.
Good man!
It is like a city one yojana long and wide, with many gates, dangerous paths, dark and frightening, but those who enter the city enjoy much comfort.
There was a man who had only one son, whom he loved very much. Hearing from afar that the pleasures in that city were like this, he immediately abandoned his son and wanted to enter the city.
This man skillfully passed through the dangerous paths, reached the city gate, and put one foot in, but before he lifted the other foot, he thought of his son.
He immediately thought like this:
I have only one son. When I came, why did I not bring him with me? Who can raise and protect him, keeping him away from all suffering?
He then abandoned the pleasant city and returned to where his son was.
Good man!

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are also like this. For the sake of compassion, they cultivate the five supernormal knowledges. Having cultivated them, they are about to exhaust their defilements but do not attain realization.
Why is it so?
Out of compassion for sentient beings, he abandoned the supernormal powers of the destruction of contaminants, and even practiced in the realm of ordinary beings.
Good man!

The city is a metaphor for the great parinirvÄá¹‡a, the many gates are a metaphor for the eighty-four thousand samÄdhi gates, the dangerous road is a metaphor for the activities of MÄra, reaching the city gate is a metaphor for the five supernormal knowledges, entering with one foot is a metaphor for wisdom, and not entering with the other foot is a metaphor for the bodhisattva not yet realizing liberation.
The only son is a metaphor for all sentient beings in the five destinies, caring for the son is a metaphor for the mind of great compassion.
Returning to where the son is is a metaphor for taming sentient beings, being able to attain liberation but not realizing it is precisely skillful means.
Good man!
The great kindness and great compassion of bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are inconceivable!
Bodhisattva Jewel Crown addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
As the Buddha has said, great kindness and great compassion are inconceivable.
It is truly as the holy teachings say, not only is compassion inconceivable, but the power of skillful means is also inconceivable.

Bodhisattvas clearly know for themselves that they will attain supreme perfect enlightenment, yet they do not realize it. For the sake of sentient beings, they engage in birth and death, yet they are not defiled by birth and death.
World-Honored One!
What dharmas do bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas possess, so that their minds do not become weary and regretful while in birth and death?
Good man!
Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas possess twenty-one dharmas, so that they do not give rise to regret while in birth and death:
First, the wholesome dharmas they cultivate are accompanied by the practice of great compassion;
Second, the compassionate mind they cultivate is accompanied by the practice of great compassion;
Third, the great compassion they cultivate is accompanied by the practice of taming sentient beings;
Fourth, taming sentient beings is accompanied by the practice of diligence;ğŸ”½Fifth, the diligence they cultivate is accompanied by the practice of wholesome mind;
Sixth, the wholesome mind they cultivate is accompanied by the practice of skillful means;
Seventh, the practiced skillful means are practiced together with wisdom;
Eighth, the cultivated wisdom is practiced together with meditation;
Ninth, the cultivated four dhyÄnas are practiced together with spiritual powers;ğŸ”½Tenth, the cultivated spiritual powers are practiced together with knowledge;
Eleventh, the cultivated knowledge is practiced together with desire;
Twelfth, the cultivated desire is practiced together with mindfulness;
Thirteenth, the cultivated mindfulness is practiced together with the bodhi mind;
Fourteenth, the cultivated bodhi is practiced together with the four means of conversion;
Fifteenth, the cultivated four means of conversion are practiced together with precepts;
Sixteenth, the cultivated precepts and observances are practiced together with much learning;
Seventeenth, the cultivated much learning is practiced together with abiding in accordance with the Dharma;
Eighteenth, abiding in accordance with the Dharma is practiced together with dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s;ğŸ”½Nineteenth, dhÄraá¹‡Ä«s are practiced together with unobstructed cognition;
Twentieth, unobstructed cognition is practiced together with the adornment of merit and virtue;
Twenty-one, adorning oneself with merit and wisdom.
These are the twenty-one dharmas of bodhisattvas, which prevent them from giving rise to weariness and regret while in saá¹ƒsÄra.
Bodhisattva Jewel Crown addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
How do bodhisattvas adorn themselves and also enable sentient beings to attain great benefits?
The Buddha said:
Good man!
If bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas are well-versed, it is called adornment; expounding it for others is called great benefit.
Furthermore, attaining great dhÄraá¹‡Ä« is called adornment; expounding it for others is called great benefit.
Furthermore, being without negligence is called adornment; taming sentient beings is called great benefit.
Furthermore, the thirty-two marks are called adornment; possessing great wisdom is called great benefit.
Furthermore, speaking softly is called adornment; practicing as one speaks is called great benefit.
Furthermore, being able to give everything is called adornment, and not seeking rewards is called great benefit.
Good man!
This is called the bodhisattva adorning his own body and also causing sentient beings to attain great benefit.
Good man!

Innumerable asaá¹ƒkhyeya kalpas ago, in a kalpa called Joyful Happiness, there was a buddha named Sarvasattva-priya-smá¹›ti TathÄgata, Arhat, Perfectly Enlightened, Perfect in Knowledge and Conduct, Well-Gone, Knower of the Secular World, Unsurpassed Person, Tamer, Teacher of Gods and Men, Buddha, World-Honored One. His buddha world was called Deva-darÅ›ana.
Good man!
Why was that kalpa called Joyful Happiness?
In that great kalpa, there were sixty thousand buddhas who appeared in the world.
At the beginning of that kalpa, the ÅšuddhÄvÄsa gods proclaimed thus:
'In this kalpa, there will be sixty thousand buddhas who appear.'
When sentient beings hear this, their minds are all filled with joy. Therefore, that eon is called 'Joyful.'
Good man!

The adornments of that buddha-land are subtle and sublime beyond measure. The happiness and excellence are like those of the heavens, with no difference. Therefore, the world is called 'Heavenly Observation.'
The land is all made of sandalwood, with no soil, sand, dust, or mist. Its fragrance pervades immeasurable buddha-lands.
Everywhere in that land, various lotus flowers emerge. Each flower has a great light that universally illuminates the land.

The sentient beings in that land all attain spiritual powers and do not tread on the ground with their feet. Not a single person dwells in the womb, but is all born by transformation. No one hears the name of a woman, nor is there the name of suffering or the three evil destinies.
All sentient beings take meditation and joy as their food. In that land, there is no mention of the three vehicles.
All are adorned with genuine gold, necklaces, heavenly crowns, and jeweled ornaments.
Although they do not shave their heads, dye their robes, or wear the kÄá¹£Äya, they are still called renunciant people.
Why is this?
Because they are free from greed for all things.
The TathÄgata in that land has the appearance of BrahmÄ Heaven, manifesting the body of BrahmÄ Heaven, expounding the essential Dharma for the bodhisattvas.
If there are bodhisattvas in other worlds who see that Buddha, they will experience great joy.
Good sons!
If that Buddha wishes to proclaim the Dharma, he ascends the great Dharma seat, seven tÄla trees above the great assembly, and always briefly expounds the Dharma.
Why is this?
Because the faculties of all sentient beings are sharp.
Although the TathÄgata speaks only one phrase, sentient beings understand a hundred thousand phrases.
The TathÄgata always speaks of the four pure dharmas.
What are the four?
First, the purity of the pÄramitÄs;
second, the purity of assisting enlightenment;
third, the purity of spiritual powers;
fourth, the purity of taming sentient beings.
At that time, there was a bodhisattva named Ratnasaá¹ƒbhava who addressed the Buddha, saying:
'World-Honored One!
How do bodhisattvas adorn their own bodies and also enable sentient beings to attain great benefits?'
That Buddha replied:
'Good man!
If bodhisattvas possess unobstructed wisdom, it is called adornment, and being able to create wisdom is called great benefit.'
At that time, when that Buddha expounded this Dharma, six thousand bodhisattvas attained the acceptance of the non-arising of dharmas.
At that time, that bodhisattva again addressed the Buddha, saying:
'World-Honored One!
How do bodhisattvas adorn the bodhi tree?'
The Buddha said:
'Good man!
If bodhisattvas are able to cultivate non-negligence, it is called adorning the bodhi tree.
What is called non-negligence?
Non-negligence is called abiding in accordance with the Dharma, and abiding in accordance with the Dharma is abiding as it is taught.

Furthermore, being heedful is called immeasurable adornment, immeasurable giving, immeasurable morality, immeasurable patience, immeasurable vigor, immeasurable meditation, immeasurable wisdom, immeasurable buddha-dharmas, immeasurable self-discipline, immeasurable adornment of merit and wisdom, making offerings to immeasurable World-Honored Buddhas, and due to possessing wisdom, immeasurable extensive learning. In order to increase wisdom, one cultivates immeasurable Å›amatha and vipaÅ›yanÄ.
Accomplishing such immeasurable dharmas is called adorning the bodhi tree and is also able to quickly attain supreme perfect enlightenment.
Good man!

All the dharmas that assist in attaining enlightenment take heedfulness as their root, possess great adornment and all wisdom, do not lose any wholesome dharmas, are far removed from all afflictions, and encompass all dharmas.

They are unobstructed in all dharmas, subdue the faculties, protect the wholesome dharmas, and do not allow them to regress. They know the proper time and the improper time, are endowed with the ten powers, the four forms of fearlessness, the supreme dharmas of the Buddha, and are called those who are not negligent.
